title: Probability and Statistics with Data Analysis

vocab.definition: The likelihood that an event will occur, expressed as a number between 0 and 1
All possible outcomes of a probability experiment
Events where the outcome of one does not affect the outcome of another
A measure of how spread out data points are from the mean

teachingNotes: Use real data sets and technology. Connect to real-world decision making. Emphasize the difference between theoretical and experimental probability.

sample.question: What are independent events?
expectedAny: events that don't affect each other
events that have no effect on each other

sample.question: What is the probability of a certain event?
What is the probability of an impossible event?

truefalse.question: Independent events do not affect each other's outcomes. (True or False)
Probability ranges from 0 to 1. (True or False)
The mean is the same as average. (True or False)
Standard deviation measures spread. (True or False)
Sample space includes impossible outcomes. (True or False)
A probability of 1 means certain. (True or False)
A probability of 0 means impossible. (True or False)
Dependent events affect each other. (True or False)
The mean is always in the data set. (True or False)
You can have a probability greater than 1. (True or False)

multiplechoice.question: What is all possible outcomes called?
What measures spread from the mean?
Events that don't affect each other are?
What is the probability of rolling a 3 on a six-sided die?
What is the probability of flipping heads on a fair coin?
If P(A) = 0.3 and P(B) = 0.4, and A and B are independent, what is P(A and B)?
What is another word for average?

fillintheblank.question: The _____ is the average of a data set.
All possible outcomes form the sample _____.
Events that don't affect each other are _____.
_____ measures how spread out data is from the mean.
A probability of _____ means the event is certain.
A probability of _____ means the event is impossible.
The _____ of an event is its likelihood.
If you roll a die, the sample space has _____ outcomes.

shortanswer.question: How do you find the mean of a data set?
expectedAny: Add all values and divide by the count
Sum divided by number of values
Total of all values divided by how many

shortanswer.question: What does standard deviation tell you?
expectedAny: How spread out data is from the mean

shortanswer.question: How do you find probability?
expectedAny: Favorable outcomes divided by total outcomes
Number of successes over total possibilities
Desired results divided by all results

shortanswer.question: What is the difference between independent and dependent events?
expectedAny: Independent don't affect each other, dependent do
Independent are separate, dependent influence each other
Independent outcomes don't change, dependent do

shortanswer.question: Why does larger sample size improve probability estimates?
expectedAny: Law of large numbers: approaches theoretical probability
More trials give more accurate estimates

shortanswer.question: What is sample space?
expectedAny: All possible outcomes of an experiment
Set of all results that can occur

shortanswer.question: For two independent events A and B, how do you find P(A and B)?
What does a probability of 0.5 mean?
expectedAny: Half the time or even odds

shortanswer.question: If you flip a coin twice, what is the sample space?
expectedAny: Four outcomes: heads-heads, heads-tails, tails-heads, tails-tails

wordProblems.question: If you flip a fair coin twice, what is the probability of getting exactly one head?
A quality control inspector finds 3 defective items in a sample of 50. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected item is defective.
What is the probability of rolling a 4 on a standard die?
If P(A) = 0.5 and P(B) = 0.6, and A and B are independent, find P(A and B).
What is the probability of drawing a heart from a standard deck of 52 cards?
A bag has 3 red and 7 blue marbles. What is the probability of drawing a red marble?
If you roll two dice, how many outcomes are in the sample space?
What is the probability of getting tails on a fair coin flip?
